page.title: 07FLITWICK PARISH CHURCH.
page.content: THE PRESENT BUILDING OF THE CHURCH OF ST. PETER AND ST. PAUL DATES FROM NORMAN TIMES, ALTHOUGH THERE WAS PROBABLY A THATCHED SAXON BUILDING ON THE SAME SITE PREVIOUSLY. THE OLDEST PART OF THE CHURCH IS THE NORTH AISLE,AND ON THE OUTSIDE WALL THERE IS AN ARCH DECORATED WITH BEAK HEAD CARVING DATING FROM THE 12TH CENTURY. UNFORTUNATELY THIS HAS BEEN DAMAGED AND SOME OF THE HEADS HAVE BEEN LOST. THE CHURCH HAS A TOWER DATING FROM 1380, HOUSING FIVE 16TH CENTURY BELLS. THE PORCH ON THE SOUTH WALL WAS BUILT IN 1500 OF LOCAL BRICK AND TIMBER. INSIDE THERE IS A NORMAN FONT WHICH USED TO HAVE A SEALED LID. THIS WAS DUE TO THE SUPERSTITION THAT EVIL SPIRITS COULD INVADE AN OPEN FONT. THERE IS ALSO A ROUNDEL OF 14TH CENTURY STAINED GLASS SHOWING THE ARMS OF SIR DAVID DE FITWICK.
